thread.title: Luke Gatti: Macaroni and cheese tantrum thrower kicked out of university? | Business News | Business and Finance News | |
thread.title_full: Luke Gatti: Macaroni and cheese tantrum thrower kicked out of university? | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Sophia Rosenbaum
title: Luke Gatti: Macaroni and cheese tantrum thrower kicked out of university? | Business News | Business and Finance News | |
text:
THE obnoxious bro who went ballistic after a University of Connecticut dining hall refused to serve him mac and cheese will now apparently be denied a diploma from the school as well.
Luke Gatti was spotted leaving the college campus on Wednesday with a car full of his belongings. “Mac and cheese kid is leaving campus. Looks like @uconn did the right thing and expelled him,” tweeted @YoungJands .
The drunk Bacon Mac and Cheese Bro has officially left the UConn campus http://t.co/uRdWaWA0WO pic.twitter.com/S2e6gu2xY0
— Barstool Sports (@barstoolsports) October 7, 2015
WARNING: GRAPHIC LANGUAGE
Campus officials refused to comment about the 19-year-old’s student status, citing federal privacy laws.
“Generally speaking, any UConn student found to have violated the provisions of the Student Code may face penalties imposed by the Division of Student Affairs that range from probation to expulsion,” a university spokesman told The Hartford Courant .
His dinner request — where he demands some “f***ing jalapeno bacon mac and cheese” from a campus cafeteria worker — went viral with more than 2.7 million views.
Luke Gatti. Source: AP
The original video has since been taken down due to a copyright claim.
Gatti had been trying to buy the mac and cheese at the university’s student union in Storrs. Police and the manager say he was refused service because he had an open alcohol container.
The nine-minute clip shows Gatti throwing a temper tantrum when a dining hall employee, whom he calls a “f***ing idiot,” denies his mac and cheese request.
The video shows Gatti arguing with and shoving the manager before being tackled by another employee, being arrested by police and spitting at the manager before being led away.
Gatti, of Bayville, New York, was charged with breaching the peace and criminal trespassing on Sunday evening. He is due back in court October 13.
He transferred to UConn from the University of Massachusetts-Amherst, where he was arrested twice in 2014 for disorderly conduct and assaulting a police officer, records show.
This article originally appeared on New York Post and was reproduced with permission.
Originally published as Bad news for mac and cheese kid
